issue.title: POC: inprocess: Support anonymous servers

repository.name: grpc-java
repository.description: The Java gRPC implementation. HTTP/2 based RPC

body:
Something like the first approach sounds good. The assumption is this is currently done at a higher level to keep the shading logic (of the java code, and rename/move of the JNI library) in a single layer but moving it into Netty sounds good to me. I will need to validate this works as expected but assuming it does I'm OK with removing `io.netty.packagePrefix` (@normanmaurer may not be though).

> io.netty may have been rewritten as a.b or com.example.shadednetty

The native code currently only supports prepending a prefix to existing netty class names. If it is desired to support arbitrary renaming then work would be needed at the JNI layer. Is support beyond appending a prefix necessary?

> The assumption is this is currently done at a higher level to keep the shading logic (of the java code, and rename/move of the JNI library) in a single layer but moving it into Netty sounds good to me.

I'm not too picky as to the solution, as long as it can be transparent to the user. While it is possible to set `io.netty.packagePrefix` via code, that can be hard/strange for a library and is not guaranteed to be permitted. It also means that every transitive user of Netty may end up needing that logic in code (not just shading configuration).

> The native code currently only supports prepending a prefix to existing netty class names. ... Is support beyond appending a prefix necessary?

Ah, that's a good point; I got so tied up with library loading I forgot the packagePrefix was used other places. I think just supporting a prefix is sufficient, but I just wanted to call out ways that my suggested change may accidentally limit existing configurations. But now that's obviously not the case :smile:.
@ejona86 - We are on the same page. +1 for moving this logic into Netty and not relying on a system property.

issue.title: Shade Netty transport

milestone.description: v1.9.0 release. Feature window closes December 18th.

repository.name: grpc-java
repository.description: The Java gRPC implementation. HTTP/2 based RPC

issue.body:
The entire transport is shaded because we wouldn't want to collide with
the unshaded form of grpc-netty.

body: @ejona86 sorry late to party due slacking during vacation =P +1 (1 sounds good.

I'll send out a PR then using the "Semi-readable implicit" approach then. Truth be told, @normanmaurer, you didn't slow down the PR at all :smile:.

Unless someone says otherwise, I'll keep `io.netty.packagePrefix` for the moment to 1) give time for users to try the implicit method and find issues and 2) ease migration from the system property. If things work out and it is redundant then it is easy to remove it in the future.
@ejona86 is that maybe something we could use the unstable api annotation for?
@johnou, not really, since there isn't an explicit API.

issue.title: Automatically detect shaded packagePrefix

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation:

Shading requires renaming binary components (.so, .dll; for tcnative,
epoll, etc). But the rename then requires setting the
io.netty.packagePrefix system property on the command line or runtime,
which is either a burden or not feasible.

If you don't rename the binary components everything appears to
work, until a dependency on a second version of the binary component is
added. At that point, only one version of the binary will be loaded...
which is what shading is supposed to prevent. So for valid shading, the
binaries must be renamed.

Modifications:

Automatically detect the package prefix by comparing the actual class
name to the non-shaded expected class name. The expected class name must
be obfuscated to prevent shading utilities from changing it.

Result:

When shading and using binary components, runtime configuration is no
longer necessary.

Pre-existing shading users that were not renaming the binary components
will break, because the packagePrefix previously defaulted to "". Since
these pre-existing users had broken configurations that only _appeared_
to work, this breakage is considered a Good Thing. Users may workaround
this breakage temporarily by setting -Dio.netty.packagePrefix= to
restore packagePrefix to "".

Fixes #6963

----

I have manually tested this with my in-progress shading in gRPC. The default was detected and behaved the same as specifying `io.netty.packagePrefix` before and after this change. Specifying `-Dio.netty.packagePrefix=` overrode the default. My shading config is still a bit broken, so I'm getting some cipher suite failures, but those were pre-existing and unrelated to defaulting the packagePrefix.

I could have returned `""` instead of throwing `UnsatisfiedLinkError` when the prefix is un-detected, but felt it was better to fail early instead of letting the binary component's linking to fail.
